Effect of calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst of WO3/SnO2 on the catalytic oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol by H2O2 Zhaoyan Zhang Quanjing Zhu Jing Ding Xin Liu Wei-Lin Dai ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, PR China Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University Shanghai 200433 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 55664678; fax: +86 21 55665701. Graphical abstract A series of WO3/SnO2 composite catalysts are prepared by co-precipitation-impregnation method and applied to the selective oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol to phthalide by using aqueous H2O2 as the oxidant. It is found that the catalyst with best catalytic performance is 25%WO3/SnO2-1023 calcined at 823K, which can be attributed to the high dispersion of tungsten species and few W6+ ions entered into SnO2 lattice. The latter inevitably decreases the amount of surface active tungsten species. It is concluded that the appropriate calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst played an important role in the structural evolution of WO3/SnO2 composite, which was beneficial to improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst. A series of WO3/SnO2 composite catalysts for the catalytic oxidation were prepared by co-precipitation-impregnation method and characterized with various techniques. The characterization results showed that the calcination temperature of the catalyst and the support was essential to the structural evolution of the WO3/SnO2. The studies of the catalytic behavior of WO3/SnO2 catalyst in the selective oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol to phthalide using aqueous H2O2 as the oxidant suggested that the optimized calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst was 1023K and 823K, respectively, which was mainly attributed to the high dispersion of tungsten species and few W6+ ions entered into SnO2 lattice. The latter will decrease inevitably the amount of surface active tungsten species. Keywords Tungsten oxide Tin dioxide Calcinations temperature 1,2-Benzenedimethanol Catalytic oxidation 1 Introduction The metal oxide, due to its simple preparation, strong surface acidic sites, high thermal stability and better catalytic activities, has been considered as a kind of useful material in the catalysis field [1]. Tin dioxide (SnO2) has been widely used as one of the most important smart and functional materials for technological and industrial applications because of its unique chemical and mechanical stabilities as well as two specific characteristics: variation in valence state and oxygen vacancies defects [2], such as transparent conductive electrodes, anode materials for lithium-ion batteries, solar energy conversion, electrochromic devices, antistatic coatings and catalysis [3–9]. So far, there are many studies on the nanocrystalline composites of SnO2 with doping WO3, and it has been reported that WO3–SnO2 composites were mainly applied in gas sensor [10–13], acid catalysis [14–18], and functional materials [19,20]. Bai et al. has investigated a novel preparation method of WO3–SnO2 nanocomposites by a two-step sol-precipitation method, and studied the effect of the preparation parameters, such as precipitation pH value, aging conditions and calcination temperature on the grain size and specific surface area of the nanocomposites [13]. They found that the incorporation of WO3 could inhibit the grain growth of SnO2, markedly enhancing the thermal stability of SnO2, conversely, the addition of SnO2 could also control the size growth of WO3 nanocrystals and improve the gas sensitivity in the SnO2/WO3 powder synthesized by chemical co-precipitation [19]. In other words, these investigations confirmed the strong interaction between WO3 and SnO2. Ma et al. found that WO3/SnO2 could catalyze the hydrolysis of dichlorodifluoromethane, which was used as solid acid catalyst, and more effective than WO3 or SnO2 [14]. Sarkar et al. used synthetic mesoporous WO3/SnO2 for the esterification of oleic acid and ethanol to produce ethyloleate, which exhibited a comparable activity [15]. Recently, Kamata et al. have reported a heterogeneous catalyst with tungsten and zinc oxides supported on SnO2 (W–Zn/SnO2), which was proved efficient for the selective oxidation of various alkenes, amines, silanes, and sulfides with aqueous H2O2 as the green oxidant [21]. It was notable that the catalyst could be recovered from the reaction mixture and reused for several times without any obvious loss of catalytic performance. Several reports have implied that WO3/SnO2 composite has a fairly promising application prospect in the field of catalytic oxidation. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no report about the effect of the calcination temperature of support and catalyst on the structure of WO3/SnO2. Additionally, the available related research on the selective oxidation of diols with WO3/SnO2 as the catalyst and H2O2 as the oxidant has been rarely reported so far. Phthalide is commonly used in the manufacturing of dyes, pharmaceuticals, bactericides, etc. The traditional synthesis process of phthalide usually resulted in serious environmental pollution, and obtained a low yield of phthalide, or required high reaction temperature, which consumed a large amount of energy [22]. However, the oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol with aqueous H2O2 as oxidant could be called as a green process for the synthesis of phthalide, owing to the avoidance of waste or pollutant. Therefore, the oxidative lactonization of 1,2-benzenedimethanol to phthalide can be taken into account as a probe reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of the catalysts. In our previous study, WO x species have been proven to be efficient active sites for oxidation reactions [23], WO3/ZrO2 catalyst displayed good activity to the oxidation reaction of 1,2-benzenedimethanol, but the cyclic efficiency of the catalyst was not desired due to the weak interaction between W species and ZrO2. However, the WO3/SnO2 showed super stability in the oxidation reaction with aqueous H2O2 as the green oxidant, and the catalyst could be reused for several times without obvious decrease of catalytic performance due to the strong interaction between W species and SnO2 [21]. In this work, a series of WO3/SnO2 catalysts were synthesized by using co-precipitation-impregnation method and the effect of calcination temperature on the structure and catalytic performance of the WO3/SnO2 catalysts was firstly investigated. The relationship between the structure and catalytic activity of the WO3/SnO2 catalyst has been briefly discussed based on characterizations including BET, TEM, XRD, UV–vis DRS, Raman and XPS. The catalytic activity results showed that the catalyst (25%WO3/SnO2-1023, 823K) exhibited the optimal catalytic performance for the oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol, suggesting that proper calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst was necessary to good catalytic performance of WO3/SnO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Sn(OH)4 was prepared by co-precipitation method as described elsewhere [24]. In a typical procedure, an aqueous solution of tin tetrachloride (50mL, 0.64M) was added dropwise to a solution of sodium hydroxide (150mL, 0.90M) under vigorous stirring. The mixture was kept vigorous stirring at 353K for 40min, and the produced precipitate (Sn(OH)4) was obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water for several times, and finally dried at 373K in air. The obtained support samples were finally calcined at certain temperature for 3h in air, and the calcined samples were denoted as SnO2-T1, where T1 (K) represents the calcination temperature of the support. The procedure for the synthesis of WO3/Sn(OH)4 and WO3/SnO2-T1 by wetness impregnation method was similar to the literature [23]. A certain amount of tungstic acid was added into aqueous solution of oxalic acid (0.2M) at 363K with vigorous stirring. When the mixture turned to be a transparent solution, the as-prepared support (2.0g) was added into the above solution. The mixture was kept stirring at 363K for 5h and the excessive water was completely evaporated at the same temperature. The catalyst was finally obtained after drying at 373K and calcined at a set temperature in air for 3h. The calcined samples were denoted as WO3/SnO2-T1, T2, where T2 (K) represents the calcination temperature of the catalyst (WO3/SnO2-R, R: room temperature, T2: calcined at T2 of WO3/Sn(OH)4). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area of samples was measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K with Micromeritics Tristar ASAP 3000 using the BET method. TEM images were obtained using a JOEL JEM 2010 microscope operating at accelerating voltage of 200kV. The ethanol-dispersed sample was mounted on a lacey carbon formvar coated Cu grid. XRD patterns of the samples (2θ ranges from 20° to 90°) were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractrometer with Cu Kα radiation operated at 40kV and 40mA. UV–vis DRS was performed with a SHIMADZU UV-2450 instrument using BaSO4 as the reference. The Raman experiments were taken by using a Jobin Yvon DiLor LabRAM I Raman spectrometer equipped with a holographic edge filter, a CCD detector and a He–Ne laser irradiated at 632.8nm. XPS spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer PHI 5000C ESCA system equipped with an Mg Kα (1253.6eV) anode and a hemispheric energy analyzer. All binding energies were calibrated by using contaminant C 1s (284.6eV) as a reference. 2.3 Activity test The activity test was carried out at 353K in a round-bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser using 50% hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant and t-BuOH as the solvent. In a typical experiment, a mixture of 1,2-benzenedimethanol (0.690g), t-BuOH (10mL) and a certain amount of catalyst were stirred in a flask for several minutes at 353K. Then, the reaction was started after adding 50wt.% aqueous H2O2 (0.67mL) into the above mixture and was stirred for a desired time. The product distribution of the catalytic oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol was identified by means of GC–MS method and was shown in Scheme 1 . The catalytic performance of the catalysts was based on the yield of phthalide. Formation of products and consumption of substrate were detected by means of GC method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 BET As we all know, specific surface area is an important factor that affects the catalytic activity, because catalyst with larger surface area can provide more active sites that are beneficial for catalytic reactions. BET specific surface areas of SnO2 and WO3/SnO2 composites calcined at different temperatures were shown in Table 1 . It was interesting that uncalcined Sn(OH)4 had the highest surface area. As the calcination temperature increased, the BET area of the as-obtained SnO2 decreased substantially. When the calcination temperature was increased up to 1273K, the surface area of SnO2 was reduced to 5 m2/g. After loading WO3 species, the BET areas of the catalyst decreased compared with the pure support. The catalyst with the support calcinated at 1023K displays the highest BET areas suggesting that the metal support interaction was higher than that in the other catalysts. Although the support calcianted at 1023K shows smaller BET values compared with the one calcinated at 823K, the surface functional groups of the support or the support structure molded during the calcination process would be more favorable for the W loading, which would result in the high BET specific areas after the preparation of the catalysts. 3.1.2 XRD patterns The powdered XRD patterns of catalysts calcined at various temperatures are presented in Fig. 1(a). The diffraction peaks of Sn(OH)4 can be indexed to (110), (101) and (211) planes that correspond the tetragonal phase of SnO2 (JCPDS NO. 41-1445). The results indicated that the co-precipitation product of SnCl4·5H2O and NaOH could directly dehydrate to SnO2 when it was dried at 373K. All of the diffraction peaks of Sn(OH)4 were broad, revealing that the Sn(OH)4 existed mainly in amorphous or the particle size of the sample was small (∼2.1nm). At this point, it must be emphasized that the broadening of the diffraction peaks distinctly reflects the nanocrystalline nature of the samples, which was even more pronounced in the case of WO3/SnO2 composite. Compared to Sn(OH)4, the intensity of the SnO2-823 diffraction peaks increased abruptly, implying that the crystallite size for the SnO2-823 became larger after annealing, and the crystallite size was calculated about 3.7nm. After doping with WO3, the intensity of diffraction peaks of SnO2 in the catalyst gradually became strong with the increase of calcination temperature. It was, meanwhile, noteworthy that the (200), (220) and (310) planes corresponding to diffraction peaks of SnO2 appeared at a calcination temperature above 823K. Whereas the calcination temperature of catalyst was risen up to 1123K, as for 25% WO3/SnO2-823, 1123K, the degree of crystallinity of SnO2 was still weaker. This could be ascribed to the presence of WO3, which might inhibit the crystallization of SnO2. Besides, from the XRD patterns we can also find that, even if the loading of WO3 was 25wt.% and the calcination temperature was increased up to 1123K, no diffraction peaks corresponding to WO3 were noticed in the XRD patterns. Nevertheless, the strong diffraction peaks of WO3 in the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst appeared at the same calcination temperature when WO3 content was 15wt.%, reported by Zhu et al. [23]. Niu reported that the addition of SnO2 could inhibit the growth of WO3 crystal particles [19]. Then, it could explain the absence of the crystalline WO3 in 25% WO3/SnO2-823 catalyst calcined at 1123K. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the XRD patterns of pure SnO2-1123 exhibited a very intense peak, yet the intensity of diffraction peaks in the 25% WO3/SnO2-823, 1123K catalyst was much weaker after loading WO3, in other words, the crystallite size of SnO2 was small. As previous research reported, WO3 supported on the surface of SnO2 particles was presented in amorphous state when the loading of WO3 was low and it could restrain the growth of SnO2 particles [13]. Fig. 1(c) shows the XRD patterns of 25% WO3/SnO2-T1, 823K with SnO2 calcined at different temperature. It can be seen that the diffraction peaks of SnO2 gradually became sharp with the increase of calcination temperature, thus the calcination temperature could effectively affect the crystallite size of SnO2. After incorporation of WO3, the intensity of SnO2 diffraction peaks increased slowly with increasing calcination temperature, but no crystalline WO3 could be detected in the catalyst until the calcination temperature of the support was increased up to 1123K. This notable scrutiny can be explained either due to the high dispersion of tungsten precursors, or the amorphous nature of the impregnated tungsten-oxide. It was noteworthy that when the calcination temperature of the support increased to 1023K, the diffraction peak corresponding to SnWO4 appeared [25]. Crystalline WO3 was observed after further increasing the calcination temperature to 1123K, suggesting that ultra-high calcination temperature was harmful to the dispersion of tungsten-oxide species. 3.1.3 TEM Fig. 2(a–d) shows the TEM images of supports and catalysts with different calcination conditions. As can be seen from Fig. 2(a and c), Sn(OH)4 was mainly amorphous while the crystal particles were formed on calcined SnO2-1023 sample, indicating that the crystalline integrity of SnO2 increased after annealing. From Fig. 2(a and b) we could find that, the crystalline nature of 25% WO3/SnO2-R, 823K was still weak after loading tungsten species, and the difference of TEM images between them was not obvious. This finding suggested that tungsten species were not agglomerate on the surface of the supports. As shown in Fig. 2(d and e), even though the calcination temperature of support was increased up to 1023K and the BET surface area of SnO2 was significantly decreased, the supported tungsten oxides had a good dispersion without any aggregation on the surface of SnO2, which also could be demonstrated by the element mappings of WO3 and SnO2 (Fig. 2(f and g)), indicating that SnO2 was an excellent support for the dispersion of tungsten species. 3.1.4 UV–vis DRS The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of different loading of WO3/SnO2 were shown in Fig. 3 . For comparison, UV–vis DRS spectra of bulk WO3 and SnO2 were also given. The patterns showed that the evident broad absorption peak at 398nm with a weak shoulder at 358nm corresponding to the crystalline WO3 appeared and the absorption peak of crystalline SnO2 at 298nm was clearly observed. Compared with SnO2-823, the absorption of the supported catalyst at the range of 300–400nm was observed, which could be ascribed to the absorption of tungsten species. No peaks at 398nm appeared in W-doped SnO2 samples with tungsten oxide content <25wt.%, suggesting that there was no crystalline WO3 or the crystalline degree of WO3 was too weak to be observed. Moreover, the weak band at 365nm corresponding to crystalline WO3 species appeared with further increasing the tungsten oxide content up to 45wt.%, indicating that excessive loading would lead to the agglomeration of WO3 species. Meanwhile, the absorption peak of the catalyst with 45% WO3 content was shifted to lower wavelength relative to bulk WO3. Both Weber et al. and Klepel et al. reported that the UV–vis DRS spectra of WO3 species would shift to a higher wavelength side with the polymeric degree of tungsten species increasing [26,27]. Therefore, the broad band in 45wt.% WO3/SnO2-823, 823K could be attributed to the low-condensed polymeric tungsten species. Fig. 3(b(A)) shows the UV–vis DRS spectrum of the catalysts with different calcination temperatures. It can be seen that no absorption peak of crystalline WO3 was obtained at 398nm even the calcination temperature was risen to 1023K, indicating that the strong interaction between W species and SnO2 and SnO2-supported could inhibit the crystallization of WO3. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 3(b(B)), even though the surface area of the support decreased with the increase of calcination temperature of the support, the absorption peak of crystalline WO3 was not observed obviously in the catalyst. This finding implied that W species had a good dispersion on the surface of support, which was in agreement with the results from XRD and TEM images. 3.1.5 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is an important technique for identifying the existing states of tungsten and stannic oxide in WO3/SnO2. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra of supported catalyst at different calcination temperature of the catalyst and the support, respectively. It was reported that bands at around 123cm−1 (B1g), 473cm−1 (Eg), 634cm−1 (A1g), 773cm−1 (B2g) could be assigned to the tetragonal structure of SnO2 [28]. Thus, in Fig. 4(A), the presence of three bands at around 633cm−1, 775cm−1, 473cm−1 corroborates the tetragonal structure of the SnO2 in agreement with XRD results. However, no discernible B1g peak was found in the Raman spectra of SnO2. Interestingly, the prominent A1g band of doped SnO2 samples was shifted to higher wave numbers than that of pure SnO2, which could be attributed to the interaction between W species and SnO2. After doping tungsten species, a new band at around 950cm−1 and a broad band at 200–360cm−1 appeared in the doped SnO2 samples. Pagnier et al. reported that the Raman spectrum of WO3 with the grain size of less than 5nm had a new band at 960cm−1, which was the result of either W=O bond or an O-W-OH bond [29]. In Mallesham's work, it was reported that the substitution of Sn4+with small sized W6+ ions would result in the lattice defects, appearing a broad band at around 200–360cm−1 [18]. Therefore, for the W-doped SnO2 catalyst prepared by wet-impregnation method, it was inferred that a part of W6+ ions were doped into the SnO2 lattice, meanwhile, another part of tungsten species existed on the surface of support with a small size less than 5nm of crystalline WO3. In addition, with increasing the calcination temperature, the vibration modes of A1g, B1g, and Eg became strong and the peak width at half height decreased, indicating that the crystallization of SnO2 was increased as enhancing the calcination temperature, which was consistent with the results of XRD. However, despite the Raman intensity of crystalline WO3 strengthened, the peak width at half height of WO3 was not significantly changed, suggesting that roasting in high temperature did not result in the agglomeration of tungsten species. The Raman intensity of the broad band at 200–360cm−1 was also improved, implying that high temperature could lead to more W6+ ions doped into the SnO2 lattice. As can be seen in Fig. 4(B), the band at 779cm−1 was obviously observed in both 25% WO3/SnO2-1123, 823K and 25% WO3/SnO2-1023, 823K catalyst, and the peak intensity of the former was stronger. Solis et al. pointed out that the peak at 779cm−1 was attributed to SnWO4 [30]. Additionally, the Raman band at 679cm−1 was found in 25% WO3/SnO2-1123, 823K catalyst. It was reported that the characteristic Raman bands of ordered crystalline WO3 presented at 805cm−1 and 715cm−1, whereas the bands of poorly ordered WO3 shifted to lower bands [31]. Thus, it could be concluded that, for 25% WO3/SnO2-1123, 823K catalyst, the band at 779cm−1 contained the Raman bands of both SnWO4 and poorly ordered WO3, which was coincident with the XRD result, the band at 679cm−1 was attributed to disordered WO3. Except 25% WO3/SnO2-1123, 823K catalyst, other WO3-dopped catalysts did not show any Raman bands at 679cm−1. This finding indicated that when using the uncalcined SnO2 or SnO2 with calcined at low temperature as the substrate, the tungsten species would have well-dispersion, conversely, the high calcination temperature of support could lead to the agglomeration of W species and increased the crystallization of the support. Compared with 25% WO3/SnO2-823, 823K, the band at around 200–360cm−1 of 25% WO3/Sn(OH)4, 823K was stronger, which implied that more W6+ ions doped into the SnO2 lattice, suggesting that the tungsten species supported on uncalcined SnO2 were much easier to dope into the SnO2 lattice. Furthermore, the broad band at 200–360nm appeared, indicating that the higher calcination temperature of support would also lead to much W6+ ions doped into SnO2 lattice. 3.1.6 XPS measurements The surface Sn/W ratio of the W-doped catalyst with different calcinations temperature obtained by XPS measurements was shown in Table 2 . The surface Sn/W ratio of all the catalysts was less than the stoichiometric value, indicating that tungsten species were mainly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst. It was noticed that the measured value (surface Sn/W ratio) was very close to the theoretically calculated one by using Sn(OH)4 as the support. As shown in BET results, the uncalcined Sn(OH)4 possessed larger specific surface area, which could be beneficial to the dispersion of tungsten species on the surface of the catalyst. Whereas using SnO2 as the carrier, the surface Sn/W ratio of catalyst decreased, and a quasi “volcano” result was obtained. It was because the Sn/W radio was not only related to the surface area of support but also the amount of W6+ entered into lattice. On the one hand, the surface area of the support decreased after calcination (BET results), which was harmful for the surface dispersion of tungsten species. On the other hand, Raman results indicated that high calcinations temperature could lead to many W6+ ions doped into the SnO2 lattice. These could explain the reason of the surface ratio (Sn/W) going through a maxima for 25%WO3/SnO2-1023, 823K catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity of different catalysts for the lactonization of 1,2-benzenedimethanol 3.2.1 Effect of different WO3 content Fig. 5 shows the catalytic results of catalysts with various contents of WO3 supported on SnO2-823. It was noticed that no catalytic activity was observed in catalyst with 10% WO3 loading. Further increasing the WO3 loading, the performance of catalyst improved accordingly, one of the reasons could be attributed to the existence of polymerized WO3 confirmed by UV–vis DRS, leading to good catalytic activity in agreement with the previous report [23]. However, the interaction between Sn and W would decrease with increasing W loading. ICP results showed that the loss amount of W species in 45%WO3/SnO2-823, 823K catalyst was much higher than the 25%WO3/SnO2-823, 823K one. So excessive loading would lead to obvious leaching of tungsten species in the reaction. It is known that homogeneous tungstic acid was excellent catalyst for this reaction, thus, 45wt.% WO3/SnO2 catalyst shows better catalytic performance because the leaching species acted as homogeneous catalyst. Considering the difficulty for recycling of homogeneous catalysts, the 45wt.% WO3/SnO2 catalyst was not studied in detail in this work. ICP results confirmed that the 25%WO3/SnO2-823, 823K catalyst showed very low leaching behavior. After three runs, the WO3 content kept constant in the reused catalyst. As for the catalyst composition, it is very difficult to get the crystal phase by XRD, even the HRTEM cannot show the lattice structure of WO3–SnO2 composite. From this work, we can assume that the surface of the catalyst may consist of the polymeric tungstic acid stabilized by Sn4+. The detailed structure will be discussed in a separated work. 3.2.2 Effect of the calcination temperature of catalysts The catalytic performance of 25%WO3/SnO2-823, T2 with different calcination temperatures of the catalyst was listed in Table 3 . As can be easily seen, the high conversion of 1,2-benzenedimethanol was obtained for the catalyst calcined at 623K. When the temperature was increased to 823K, even the conversion of the substrate decreased, but the selectivity of phthalide was slightly improved (from 60.6 to 64.8%). Nevertheless, further improving the calcination temperature of catalyst, the catalytic activities were significantly decreased. If the calcination temperature was risen up to 1123K, the catalyst was inactive and the selectivity of the product was only 9.3%. Although the characterization results from XRD and UV–vis DRS indicated that no crystalline WO3 was obviously formed in the catalysts with increasing the calcination temperature, Raman measurements revealed that more W6+ ions were doped into the SnO2-supported lattice with high calcination temperature of the catalyst. This result explained the poor activities for the catalysts. 3.2.3 Effect of supports with different calcination temperature As can be seen from Table 4 , with increasing the calcination temperature of the support, even though the conversion of 1,2-benzenedimethanol obviously enhanced, the selectivity of target product decreased. The catalyst with SnO2-support calcined at 1023K performed the best selectivity among the catalysts and the selectivity of target product achieved 69.2%. When using the uncalcined Sn(OH)4 as the support, the catalytic activity of catalyst was very poor and the selectivity of phthalide was only 4%. The poor selectivity of W-doped Sn(OH)4 was due to more W6+ ions entered into the support lattice, despite of the high dispersion of tungsten species on the surface of the catalyst, according to the XRD, Raman and XPS characterization. For the 25% WO3/SnO2-823, 1023K catalyst, most tungsten species were dispersed on the surface of the support and only few W6+ ions entered into the lattice, which could explain the good catalytic activity. As the support was calcined at 1123K, agglomeration of tungsten species would happen due to the small surface area of the support, and the poorly ordered crystalline WO3 was formed as well, which leaded to the decreased catalytic performance. Another interesting finding was that SnWO4 was formed in both 25% WO3/SnO2-1123, 823K and 25% WO3/SnO2-1023, 823K catalyst, however, from their catalytic results we could infer that SnWO4 had no significant influence on the catalytic activity of catalyst. 4 Conclusion The catalytic activity of WO3/SnO2 prepared by co-precipitation-impregnation method for the selective oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol was strongly affected by the calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst. The characterization and catalytic test results showed that the optimized calcination temperature of the support and catalyst was 1023K and 823K, respectively, as for this catalyst, HRTEM and element mapping showed that W species were highly dispersed on the support. When the calcination temperature of catalyst is too low, the W species could not be activated, conversely, many W6+ ions entered into SnO2 lattice at high calcination temperature. Additionally, XRD results showed that there was mutually inhibition between SnO2 and W species in crystallization. Raman and XPS results showed that when the support was not calcinated, there were too many W6+ ions entered into the lattice of SnO2. If increasing the calcination temperature of the support up to 1123K, the tungsten species began to aggregate, leading to poorly catalytic performance of the catalysts in the selective oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol to phthalide. Therefore, the appropriate calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst played an important role in the structural evolution of WO3/SnO2 composite, which was beneficial to improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A series of WO3/SnO2 composite catalysts for the catalytic oxidation were prepared by co-precipitation-impregnation method and characterized with various techniques. The characterization results showed that the calcination temperature of the catalyst and the support was essential to the structural evolution of the WO3/SnO2. The studies of the catalytic behavior of WO3/SnO2 catalyst in the selective oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol to phthalide using aqueous H2O2 as the oxidant suggested that the optimized calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst was 1023K and 823K, respectively, which was mainly attributed to the high dispersion of tungsten species and few W6+ ions entered into SnO2 lattice. The latter will decrease inevitably the amount of surface active tungsten species.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of calcination temperature of the support and the catalyst of WO3/SnO2 on the catalytic oxidation of 1,2-benzenedimethanol by H2O2
